Much like the director's seminal doc, this is a richly-drawn slice of real life that's weaved with the finesse of a fine Hollywood drama.
Brushing aside decades of nostalgia, this is a whip-smart postmodern romp with a warm heart to boot, and as such, it should please both life-long fans and new initiates to the Muppet universe.
Ambitious, stunningly-acted, smart, and astoundingly not outstaying its welcome despite a beefy run time, Margaret is destined to become a cult classic.
The film's already gut-wrenching sense of paranoia and dread is wholly accentuated by Elizabeth Olsen's searing, nuanced breakthrough performance.
Trumping even genre classic Rocky, Warrior packs a grand emotional wallop thanks to top-tier performances and the fact that you don't want either fighter to lose.
The fiercely intelligent Contagion outdoes its genre competition precisely because it doesn't dumb itself down for our sake.
Scorsese's unlikely 3D family film takes an agreeably pragmatic stance, that we must embrace the past yet never deny progress.
This third film, an inarguably powerful knockout punch, reminds us of the documentary film's power to change people's lives.
The deeply-felt chemistry between Felicity Jones and Anton Yelchin helps Like Crazy to capture the tragic ironies of young love in a diverting, mature, and ultimately heartbreaking manner.
It might not be quite as insulting a Best Picture nominee as The Blind Side, but it's incredibly close.
It is easy to admire this film's goofy charm, its odd lack of desperation to seek your approval, to simply sling as much lunacy at the screen as possible and hope that some of it sticks.
A competently-acted but utterly forgettable procedural that's full of exasperatingly idiotic character decisions due to lazy scripting.
Rent-a-hack McG directs this brain-damaged screenplay with the skill of a particularly deficient farm animal, and humiliates three talented actors in the process.
Lacking even the perverse pleasure of a memorable Nicolas Cage performance, this messy superhero pic conjures unpleasant memories of what was until now Marvel's biggest comic book failure, Elektra.
Hollywood's own family fare could probably learn a little from this sweet-natured and surprisingly affecting Aussie hit.
No matter how many dimensions you slap on the poster, there's no accounting for lazy workmanship. Can Robert Rodriguez please make Sin City 2 now?
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: So unforgivably, soul-destroying bad it'll have you wishing Pacino had made Righteous Kill 2 instead.
Most peculiar of all are the film's genuinely violent interludes, which unexpectedly shift the tone and stifle the comedy, and boy, this is one film that doesn't need any help being unfunny.
After starring in The Expendables, was Dolph Lundgren really strapped enough for cash to star in this?
movie_title: In The Name Of The King: Two Worlds (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Michel Hazanavicius' spellbinding love-letter to silent cinema is a masterclass of inscrutable production design, top-notch physical comedy, and a postmodern sensibility which never descends into a rose-tintedly overzealous adulation of the era.

Ryan Gosling is astonishing in this thrilling and timely - if also bleak - political allegory, which skilfully reflects Obama-era disappointment and also functions as a concise riff on morality, role models and the dangers of idealism.

A winningly understated performance from John C. Reilly and a potentially star-making turn from lead Jacob Wysocki help place Terri's firm finger on the pulse of the often senselessly cruel high school experience.

Paranormal Activity 3, which parts audiences once again with their cash while refusing to move the series' mythology forward, will frustrate those expecting any sort of continuation from the last film, despite some decent scares.
No, it's not Sideways, but Alexander Payne's emotionally complex drama is hilarious and heartfelt in equal measure, boosted by a stellar turn from George Clooney.
The Dardennes' depiction of a courageous fight for childhood boasts one of the best child performances in some time, from impressive newcomer Thomas Doret.
A Dangerous Method is probably the tamest film David Cronenberg will ever make, but it is nevertheless worthy as a well-acted skewering of overreaching psychology.
In the mayhem-for-minutes stakes, few films can dream to live up to the sheer economy of Roman Polanski's deliciously acid-tongued 79-minute chamber piece.
In Time is half a good film - thoughtful, well-shot, and smart in places - and half a clunky, derivative, and at its worst, laughable one.
Arthur Christmas strains so much to be a postmodern Yuletide yarn that it forsakes the much-needed sprinkle of Christmas spirit and concedes too much of the Santa myth in the process.
The occasionally amusing Twilight Saga finds a new low with the dramatically inert, painfully dull Breaking Dawn Part 1.
While too eager to adhere to the vague indiecore schematic, Another Earth is a visual stunner and provides a strong platform for both director Cahill and impressive lead actress Brit Marling.
Despite its visual sophistication and a good lead performance, there's no escaping that this Thing is a pointless remake trying to convince itself that it is in fact a prequel.

Despite having amassed a roster of roughly thirty bonafide film stars and respected character actors, New Year's Eve is nothing more than a glorified cameo carousel, and a laughably schmaltzy, punishingly dull one at that.
Ultimately, it's further proof that Katherine Heigl picks her projects by stapling all potential scripts to a wall and throwing a dart.
Retaining the series' innate goofiness while taking the action and emotional stakes to new highs, this is the best Mission: Impossible yet.
While its fairytale-inspired premise lacks the subversive wit of the better Shrek films, Puss in Boots is an agreeably snappy, visually enticing yarn nonetheless.

Much like the first Sherlock, the good work by Downey Jr. and Law is largely undone by flat humour, stilted action and a dull, breadcrumb-following plot unbecoming of Doyle's beloved detective. The ending, though, is much better than the film deserves.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This strangely surreal, tediously conceited travelogue of Margaret Thatcher's personal and professional highs and lows is notable only for Meryl Streep's chameleonic performance.

David Fincher's first-rate direction effortlessly wipes the floor with the soporific Swedish counterpart. In the end, though, even Fincher can't froth up some of the novel's more procedural killer-of-the-week fancies.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This prickly and challenging film smartly confronts our expectations of the character-driven drama, and thanks to Charlize Theron and Patton Oswalt's impressive performances, has the makings of a cult favourite.
Spielberg's latest is an overly sweet spectacle but a wildly exhilarating one; near-flawless on a technical level if too eager to make your heart soar.
The best-looking bad film of 2011, I Melt with You squanders a fine acting quartet with self-indulgent existential angst among characters who are impossible to like.
It's little surprise that Daniel Craig and Rachel Weisz disowned this turgid, woefully inept thriller which idiotically gave away its big reveal in the trailer.
It's a sequel nobody asked for, and unsurprisingly, it sucks.
Surely too much money has been spent on the cast and the 3D rather than on fashioning an intelligent, funny script.
This dubious distillation of Ayn Rand's objectivist philosophy is a glorified smack around the head with a sociology textbook.
Kate Hudson's career suicide continues with the devastatingly unfunny, tonally jarring A Little Bit of Heaven.
Catherine Hardwicke, what the Hell happened?
It's frighteningly impressive that a one-note gag has spawned three dreadful films and hundreds of millions of dollars in box office receipts. Wherever will they go next? Big Mommas 3D?
movie_title: Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With all the digital and environmental tomfoolery, it's a shock that Chipwrecked wasn't released in 3D, and that renders it ever so slightly more respectable. But seriously, Jason Lee, you're so much better than this. Please, stop now.
Thoroughly hit-and-miss, Wanderlust nevertheless entertains as a rambunctious oddity with a cracking supporting line-up.
In the stakes of kitchen-sink cinema, perhaps no film has so proudly put its empty, inside-out pockets on display for all to see as Nick Nevern's Terry.

This is a trenchant and thought-provoking treatise on modern families, specifically the put-upon mother, whose role is to raise, to nurture, and tragically, to account for the terrible things her children might do.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Chris Rock delivers a performance of unexpected nuance in Julie Delpy's personal, uproariously funny follow-up to 2 Days in Paris.
The cast gives it their all, but this tepid dramedy lacks fervour and originality.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An early surprise for the summer, Men in Black 3 defies the odds as a fun, flawed romp with an unexpectedly sweet, affecting climax. But they need to call it a day here.
More The Dark Knight than Twilight, this is one fairytale update that packs an impressive punch and a deft, human touch.

Scott's most well-rounded and accomplished feature since his classic Blade Runner thirty years ago. Seek it out for yourself and again remember that imaginative, daring sci-fi is out there for the finding.
Much like Lumet's Network, Death Watch grows only more unsettling as the years pass.
movie_title: La Mort en direct (Death Watch) (Death in Full View) (1980)

movie_review_blurb: Sono's latest is overlong and fidgety, but puts its post-Fukushima context to good use.

The most vital and moving sociological document of our times remains invigorating despite mostly maintaining the status quo because by now the "characters", older, balder, and podgier, are like old friends.
It has a spellbinding heft of charm, carrying itself just like a fine whiskey - warm, a little sweet, and unequivocally a joy to return to time and time again.
A nice diversion from multiplex fare if resolutely 'special interest', On the Sly is as unassuming as its title suggests, and performed with real conviction
movie_title: À pas de loup (On the Sly) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: This micro-budget horror falls prey to its own low-fi construction, but more importantly, a real poverty of original ideas.
A breezy distillation of Allen's body of work, if inevitably glossing over his colourful personal life.
There are intelligent and provocative ideas within Kim Ki-duk's unbearably self-serving docudrama, but the auteur should stick to what he knows best.
A stylish and well-acted if disappointingly rote paranormal gumshoe story.
Possibly the best John Woo film that John Woo never made, The Raid is a skull-splintering slice of wish fulfillment.
Like a supermarket enchilada, it initially seems appealing but you quickly realise it lacks flavour.
The man has lived an incredible life, and this comprehensive doc conveys that in compelling fashion.
An embarrassing vehicle for its lead and the worst ad for Y-fronts in years.
As a story, Rock of Ages is all over the place, but the performers are clearly having a blast, and their enjoyment is infectious.
Less a passionate examination to be championed, and more a vital historical document to be admired.
Virtually defining style over substance, Requiem for a Killer disappoints on almost all fronts.
movie_title: Requiem for a Killer (Requiem pour une Tueuse) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Scant time travel logic aside, Dana Lustig might finally have found her groove with this unassuming, low-budget sci-fi.
As a precursor to better zombie films, it remains an important, passably entertaining genre milestone.
It's melodramatic to the point of lunacy, but an intense ride you won't soon forget.
Even over a half-century on, The Apartment remains a biting classic due to its modern romantic sensibilities and Lemmon's commanding, thoroughly charming central performance.
Brimming with smart ideas - not to mention a stellar turn from Bowie - but roughly-hewn and completely excessive.
movie_title: The Man Who Fell to Earth (1976)

movie_review_blurb: So portentous and superficially philosophical, it plays like art-house self-parody, betraying Erdem's visual grandeur in the process.
It remains an influence on the modern blockbuster, and is one of its best examples.
A minor period work with its share of flaws - the pacing is not great, and it is an unapologetic chamber piece - but as a look at artistic oppression...it is effective enough.
movie_title: 3 sezony v pekle (3 Seasons in Hell) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Deserves a fate better than collecting dust, especially when its potential cult status is written all over it from frame one.
It functions primarily as a reminder that Cuba Gooding Jr. is still alive and touting for work.
Icíar Bollaín melds passionate art with profound politics in this well-conceived, brilliantly acted drama.
This quietly tense drama piercingly probes the travails of young girls on the cusp of womanhood, with all of the hormone-fuelled jealousy, duplicity and confusion that this entails.
Bare-bones technical chops allow two outstanding young actors to hog the limelight in this nail-biting Romanian thriller-drama.
movie_title: If I Want To Whistle, I Whistle (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to Call of Duty: The Movie
21 Jump Street is that rarest of comedies, a classic in the making that manages to become both more outrageous and hilarious as it bounds along.
The finest horror comedy in years, The Cabin in the Woods is a potent, hilarious apology for decades of generic horror fare.
The shameless manipulation on display here makes one wonder where Cameron Crowe's talent has gone.
Derivative and overlong for sure, The Hunger Games still has just enough bite for teens likely to find Battle Royale a little too unwieldy.
This is just more of the same from Tarsem Singh; high camp and low energy, with decent visuals which in no way compensate for the script's charmless monotony.
Like almost all dance films, Streetdance 2 has failed to find extremely talented dancers who are also even remotely credible actors.
The only thing shabbier than the dull, near-incomprehensible night-time cinematography is the shopworn script.
With the punishingly dull, endlessly monotonous Battleship, Peter Berg has given the term "a poor man's Michael Bay" credibility, and that's a scary thing.
Another squandering of Amanda Seyfried's talent, this low-mileage thriller won't be remembered for long.
Sometimes, it is all about tone, and while Lockout has enough flaws to shake several sticks at, it is a film entirely in the vein of the silly, riotously fun John Carpenter sci-fi forays of the 80s
A bizarre and original comedy which offsets its narrative flaws with prevailing chemistry between Blunt and McGregor.
Probably hoping audiences will mistakenly assume this to be a comic book spin-off, the cynically-titled Fury is a derivative, low-energy slog pretty much from start to finish.
Good documentaries make us want to know more about their subject. But great ones like Marley don't need to.
This super-charged blockbuster is a mammoth spectacle which takes the genre to dizzying, rarely-seen heights.
Shamelessly sentimental, but because of its emotional honesty, this slice of pie - hopefully the last - is satisfying to the final bite.
Broaching tough material in a tactful, sensitive manner, Monsieur Lazhar is a potent, stirring gem of Canadian cinema.
The Dictator is certainly one of the most outrageous and distasteful ventures ever put to film. It is also pretty funny, too.
Armchair philosophy and scarcely likable characters make Yûya Ishii's disappointing latest feature more of a challenge than a treat.
Not quite the feel-good farce you might expect, this is an uneven but sober work about the pragmatic nature of relationships.
This brilliantly acted film is another home run for The Brothers Duplass; life affirming and sure to put a spring in your step.
Though not as inventively gory as the previous Piranha, the riotously funny cameos make it worth another go.
After the commanding opulence of Sokurov's better work, this languid trawl through Faust feels like quite the comedown.
Like cameraman Dax, we're the only sober one at the party, and it's not much fun.
I cannot imagine what compelled Mel Gibson to star in something like this, but I am glad that he did.
A half-baked auto-update of the classic series, and a suggestion that Burton's persistent style has finally worn thin.
At once a paean and a eulogy to that unforgettable first love, Mia Hansen-Løve's latest feature is a refreshingly frank look at young adult relationships.
movie_title: Un amour de jeunesse (Goodbye First Love) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Fans of The Stath will find themselves very much at home with this well-acted, stylishly-shot actioner which boasts more depth than one would reasonably expect.
Elizabeth Olsen is perfectly committed to her role, yet once you get past the technical wizardry, it - like the Uruguayan original - quickly becomes tedious.
Carné's thrilling film is an important and undervalued influence on the post-war American noirs of the 1940s.
movie_title: Port of Shadows (Le Quai des Brumes) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It is dispiriting to see Efron fall prey to the most dangerous rival of artistic expression facing young actors today: the Nicholas Sparks adaptation.
Drama so perfectly wrought is hard to come by. Vallée and his stellar cast have carved out a challenging, emotionally rich film which is not shaken easily.
The inherently likeable Cusack fares surprisingly well in one of his darkest roles, but The Raven's clever premise is totally undermined by James McTeigue's tactless, bumbling direction.

Woody Harrelson's compelling performance as a man desperately trying to escape a net drawing ever tighter - yet fundamentally refusing to change his ways - ensures this gripping and gritty crime drama amounts to being more than just The Shield: The Movie.
Cue self pity, followed by despair, followed by resignation, hope and redemption...Screenwriter/director Dan Rush...opts for this standard redemption arc.
How easily you'll weather the film depends on your taste for poetic, obtuse cinema, often without too much of a rhyme or reason.
As dubious as the original, though easier to watch in several ways.

What makes True Grit truly brilliant, however, isn't just the Coens' reverence for the style and tone of the Westerns of yesteryear, but the John Ford-inspired manner in which they manage to both epitomise and eulogise the myth of the Old West...
[C]ertainly not the worst thing you could have sat through this year so far, but it lacks any flavour or verve; it is a hollow shade rather than the vibrant, jovial caper it should be.

Not even a good effort from Matt Dillon -- who seems to play the hard-done-by cop/security guard for the umpteenth time here -- can provide this stodgy outing with the caffeine kick it is sorely in need of.
What can be learned from Exorcismus? When left to their own devices, financial economists don't typically make very good screenwriters.

That the project is not only a success but one of 2010′s best films is a testament to Fincher's talent as a director and his seemingly perennial ability to surround himself with incredibly astute, like-minded collaborators.
If you're not spitting bile by the end of Inside Job, check your pulse.
Undeniably one of the greatest films of the 1980s and indeed, of all time, Back to the Future has endured so well because it walks that fine tightrope of managing to appeal to just about everyone...

The incredible first act boasts more horror, surprise and intrigue than most fully-formed features, and though the subsequent hour never feels as concise or gathered, this is a potent, almost unbearably visceral slice of confronting cinema.

With his recent glut of increasingly low-rent cinematic forays...combined with the blatantly obvious fact that he's only making them to stave off bankruptcy, Nicolas Cage may have subjected himself to a whole new subgenre of filmmaking - Cagesploitation.

Essentially Deliverance cross-bred with A History of Violence...Leaves of Grass is a peculiar rural yarn and a sweet, assured examination of lost innocence and brotherhood that succeeds largely because of Norton's multi-faceted performance.
Howl's biggest triumph, however, is that it never forces the viewer to revere the titular poem beyond its eminent value in testing the limits of society's tolerance.
It's ultimately a pastiche-by-numbers and doesn't live up to its full potential, but as a visual treat and one of Depp's better vehicles of recent years, it delivers the basic goods.
The triumvirate of focal performances -- especially the Oscar-nominated Nicole Kidman as the grieving mother -- will break your heart.
Brighton Rock is a classic example of filmmaking that remains hugely accessible despite its age...

How much you'll enjoy Due Date depends more on your esteem for the leads rather than the quality of the screenplay; it is a mess of emotions and situations, working more than not, though tainted by that air of laziness that the entire production invites.

When the dystopian future envisioned in Blade Runner finally comes to fruition, Age of the Dragons will be used to distinguish humans from replicants, because if you're not in teary despair by the film's end, you probably aren't human.
Client 9 probably won't make you like Elliot Spitzer, but it will damn sure make you respect him.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It gets no points for subtlety, but this confronting, devastating, hilarious and extremely fun film is a masterpiece all in its own right.

It won't make a dent in the box office and it can hardly be considered essential viewing, but it's serene, unpretentious, and boasts more than enough cute moments to justify its existence. Parents, I imagine, will love it.
I'm sure many people on both sides of the fence will relate to these characters, though they probably won't tell their partners.
No matter how loud the tension chord, The Resident is funnier than it is frightening.
While on the slick exterior Liman has crafted a gripping thriller, at its core this is as much a romance and paean to the ties of marriage.
For all of its many flaws, anyone who has ever struggled with unemployment will find this to be an incredibly sober work.
Despite plenty of promise, it's a mirthlessly clichéd, spasmodic mess of editing and direction. Still, look on the bright side; at least it wasn't released in 3D.
For anyone who can be bothered to read subtitles, it is essentially a pointless endeavour, but Let Me In has a strident regard for what made the original so enthralling...
With a stronger ending Source Code could have been great; as it stands, it's still a thrilling entertainment destined for cult status.

This airy, quiet meditation on the struggle of three people to transcend abject poverty and unexpected loss will likely play as too dialled-down for many tastes, but persevering with it will reveal a rare, peculiar mystical quality...
The Lincoln Lawyer sees Matthew McConaughey rise from the embers of Hollywood mediocrity like a Phoenix, soaring like he hasn't in years.
Blunt and Damon have delightful chemistry, but this is still little more than a derivative, campy B-movie, which would be fine if it was at all what the filmmakers had intended.
It at times dabbles too often in crime cliches - as though written by someone coming off of a Sopranos box-set bender - but it is also uncomfortably tense and unsettlingly brutal.
[S]urely the worst thing James Cameron has dared waft his fortune close to.
Duvall's work here has little in way of grand emotional declarations or Oscar-reel moments, but it is a calmly anguished, fiercely committed turn.
There is a profound sense of Neorealism percolating beneath Winter's Bone's noirish mystery plot.
[M]ost of its promise is squandered through inept scripting and a failure to indulge a self-aware enthusiasm for its B-movie concept.

Adam Green's fun 2006 horror film Hatchet revelled in the art of self-aware pastiche, but it is in his second major work that he has found a legitimately great concept out of which to wring more nuanced thrills.
[W]hile there is a power to this tale of triumph, it is measured against the cold calculation of the familiar Brit-com treatment.
It is a film almost unremittingly hopeless in its cruel finality, packing a crucial emotional punch, ending with a chilling monologue that reminds us of the tale's universality.
Genuinely, it deserves a fate better than collecting dust, especially when its potential cult status is written all over it from frame one.
As with any of Morris' documentaries, Tabloid is thematically rich beyond the bounds of its central focus.
Taipei Exchanges is a pleasantly minimalistic effort from Hsiao Ya-Chuan, and though it hardly puts Taiwanese cinema on the map, it is a light, fleetingly entertaining drama...
It goes without saying that the precocious charm of an impoverished Rwandan kid improvising a football out of a condom, some string and a plastic bag is undeniable.
Evidently, Mike Leigh shows no signs of slowing down as he -- like his characters in Another Year -- ventures close to old age.
[A] title card end[s] the film on another ominous ellipsis, ominous primarily because it guarantees the need for a third film, most likely to be released in 3D, it is assumed.
Mullan is smart enough not to close his subject off; many questions remain, and true to the nature of social mobility, little is ever solved quickly.

Metz cares not to moralise or cut the footage to assume any particular viewpoint, instead he merely conveys the confused mania of war, tragically capturing the anguish of the frustrated civilians caught between soldiers and the Taliban.

The epic, game-changing twist of an ending which brings the series effectively full circle, is so ridiculously, even laughably over-the-top and off-the-rails that it feels more akin to the quirky, self-aware tone set by the last film.

The success of the film lives and dies with Bardem, for while it is moving and dramatically potent, the grim reality of Iñárritu's well-thumbed worldview may have proven too unwieldy in the hands of a lesser actor.

Benedek Fliegauf's haunting, well-shot film is a riveting sci-fi drama with an engrossing central performance and a thoughtful, surprisingly tasteful engagement with the concept of lost love and the lengths people will go to regain it.

Gregg Araki has made a career out of sex and sexuality parables; his work is sexy, and at first glance perhaps low-brow exploitation, but like few filmmakers, his work eagerly ponders the sliding scale of human sexuality.
There is a tragic craft to how one manages to make a film about 'the greatest swordsman who has ever lived' as boring as The Warrior's Way.
Straying from a predictable, easily defined structure, Megamind instead serves up consistent surprises, challenging audience expectations and engaging the mind as well as tickling the funny bone.
Monsters virtually redefines guerilla filmmaking for our technologically attuned generation, and despite its many flaws, it is an enticing career-maker for director Edwards.
Brevity is the soul of wit, and while Helander seems to understand this with his snappy runtime, there is only barely enough new material here to justify a feature production.
The Tourist is best considered an expensive travel ad for Venice rather than the sexy, action-packed, sassy thriller we were all hoping for.
[M]eek fantasy fare that's overbudgeted, underwritten, and while it may have happened this way in the novel, that doesn't mean it is any good, nor that we should give it a free pass...
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: That talents like De Niro and Stiller would sign off on such a turgid and bone idle attempt to part families with their Christmas cash is stultifying.
127 Hours is ultimately about a man wrestling with his own hubristic mode of living, and paying a price for it, but living.
Hooper has teased out of the brilliant script and Oscar-worthy central performances an electric crowd-pleaser that borrows the best of Brit period cinema...while eliding the very worst.
Avoid it -- wait for it -- like the Black Plague.
The fact that it is directed with a sub-Shawshank regard for tact and restraint is neither here nor there; this is a potent, superbly-acted tale of determination in the face of enormous adversity...
Painstakingly and heartbreakingly, the formula of the romantic drama has its neck wrung here; the story of boy-meets-girl exists only with our prior knowledge that it is doomed...

Essentially a stitched together patchwork of better films albeit without their sense of horror, intelligence or humour, this is bargain bin fodder that somehow crawled out of the primordial soup long enough to gain a theatrical run.

Social commentary, you ask? Quite how can a film centrally preoccupied with Danny Trejo stabbing and shooting people and having sex with lots of women have any sort of pretension to political currency?
Ironically for a film so keenly centred on the idea of reaching one's own potential, Limitless doesn't nearly begin to realise its own.
If for some reason you thought you couldn't get bored of watching a former WWE champion lurching around shooting people in the head, you were wrong.
Stone is an unusual film which shifts uneasily between sleaze and philosophy, but it's distinguished at all times by three luminous performances.
Tucker and Dale vs Evil, much like the titular characters, is daft and doesn't much care for subtlety, but smart horror fans will laugh their way through this well-acted, subversive horror-comedy.

The Troll Hunter may sound like something you'd drunkenly chance upon at a midnight drive-in, but it's a consistently thrilling, surprisingly intriguing creature feature that demonstrates there's still plenty of wiggle room in the found footage subgenre.
This slack and rather pointless retread is funnier than the original though not at all scary as it trundles towards its predictable conclusion.
Fans of low-budget indie horror might be able to forgive it, but for the rest of us it frustratingly squanders some eerie promise.
McKee is a real voice for the horror genre; he doesn't let the violence negate his keen-eyed examination of middle-class insulation, nor the other way around.
An unnecessary remake perhaps, but a knowingly updated one, with strong work from Colin Farrell and David Tennant. This film is great fun.
West's latest feature is well-directed and funny, but low on scares and quite camp, presumably unintentionally so.

At 84 minutes, this is a breezy holiday horror which doesn't outstay its welcome and has a dash of wit to go along with the ridiculous premise, not to mention firm, stylish direction despite the low budget.
Delivers a compelling, unique spin on the vampire mythos despite a subterranean budget. Hopefully Leberecht will attract plenty of attention as a result.
This gripping Swiss horror plays out like a grisly fairytale, with solid performances and impressive, visually sumptuous direction.
Even with a predictable final twist, this is the most terrifying and audacious British horror film in years.
It goes to such painstaking lengths for stylistic plausibility that the end product is actually quite dull, squandering its novel 'Paranormal Activity in space' concept as a result.
This exquisitely directed, wonderfully acted old-school thriller is a major all-rounder Awards contender, and just might secure Gary Oldman that nomination he's been deserving for so many years.
A cynical mash-up of Besson's Leon and Nikita, though without their depth of character or emotional warmth.
Plenty diverting from a stylistic perspective, but the story behind the flair is positively stone-age.
Melissa George's Scottish accent is absolutely dreadful, but the smart script and wince-inducing action make it hard to notice or care all that much.
Yet another embarrassing squandering of John Singleton's talent, and proof that Taylor Lautner isn't ready to carry a film on his broad shoulders.
Little more than a brain damaged, irony-free, and curiously toothless attempt to retread the success of last year's surprising summer gorefest, Piranha 3D.
Utterly preposterous, but Panic Button is gripping and a lot of fun.
This is not a pleasant film, nor one you will probably want to watch again anytime soon. But the volcanic, award-worthy performances from Peter Mullan and Olivia Colman make it an absolute must see.
In the face of a decade of cynical misanthropy, the optimistic and effervescent Midnight in Paris is Allen's most purely enjoyable work in years.

More successful as a rock 'em, sock 'em 'Rocky with Robots' vehicle than as a potent family drama, Real Steel is a scrappy but warm-hearted film which should nevertheless appeal to just about every boy under the age of 12.
Morgan Spurlock brings an affable everyman charm to this mind-bendingly insightful critique of a world awash in commercial calculations at every corner.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: There are some compelling performances here - especially Foster and Hopkins - but they are held at the mercy of tiresome armchair philosophy and an almost fetishistic focus on silly people and the misery they cause.
Gens' disaster pic has visual flair aplenty and an explosive third reel which mostly forgives the inoffensively routine first two.

Nimbly switching gears between heartful drama and uproarious comedy, 50/50 tackles the near-impossible and makes a film about cancer that'll have you crying like a baby one minute and laughing so hard your sides hurt the next.
Deeply unsettling and blisteringly intense, Steve McQueen's sophomore feature mines smart psychology and a magnificent, Oscar-worthy performance from Michael Fassbender for all they're worth.
It's a dizzying mess of perspectives and lacks a firm head on its shoulders, but history buffs will find this assembly of footage - largely unseen outside of Sweden - to be riveting and important.

Dragonslayer - which incredulously picked up the Best Documentary award at SXSW - is probably the first ever hagiography made about someone who is, without doubt, completely unremarkable. But at least at 74-minutes, it won't keep you for too long.
Spielberg has crafted a fantastical 3D adventure which is by turns visually stunning, thrilling, sophisticated, silly, and a whole lot of fun.

Certainly challenging in its length and sparseness, Melancholia nevertheless offers up transcendent visuals, and with Kirsten Dunst's career-best performance, a stunningly authentic portrayal of depression.

The kill-or-be-killed twist could have made this the best Destination since the first, but the idea is woefully underdeveloped even if the film is nevertheless gorier and smarter than the diabolical fourth instalment.
It's all very good-looking and you don't need gore to sell a good horror flick, but you do need something in its place, like suspense. You won't be afraid of this film.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Gorgeously mounted and superbly acted, Pedro Almodóvar doesn't make this bracingly intense, off-the-wall story an excuse to forsake the humanist interests that populate his best works. And this sits proudly among them.
Uncle Boonmee is a film that feels like some sort of skewed satire on the sort of drivel people will digest as art...
movie_title: Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It offers few surprises, and for your buck all you'll essentially get is a cringe-inducing dance number, lame gags and an admittedly alluring display of oversized chocolate. Avoid.
Fundamentally dry and somewhat hamstrung by its own artful restraint, Oranges and Sunshine nevertheless works on the basis of its riveting performances.
Passenger Side is strictly a chamber piece. That chamber just happens to be the bustling, visually diverse landscape of Los Angeles.

It's a stretch to stomach Seth Green's face having been reverse-engineered onto that of a 9-year-old boy...but Mars Needs Moms stands among few animated films able to scarcely broach that problematic uncanny valley.
Rio is difficult to watch without imagining it was a light bulb idea bandied around the office of the Rio de Janeiro Tourist Board...
Slack pacing aside, this is a disarmingly brutal, feral social satire.
Short and sweet, Winnie the Pooh positively refuses to outstay its welcome. It takes us by the hand and quietly reminds us of a simpler time when 3D and CGI were a mere twinkle in someone's eye.
Far from the frat-boys-on-a-mission jaunt it should have been, Your Highness proves that a bad fantasy film with swearing and dick jokes is still a bad fantasy film.
Not without its moments, but ultimately it's too much about privileged people and their "problems". It's like an overlong Woody Allen film minus the wit and self-aware middle-class mockery.
Minimalist to the point of self-indulgence though admirable in its economy, Cold Weather is a very different kind of thriller. Think Brick by way of Arthur Conan Doyle.

It's not nearly as bad as you've probably heard, thanks to a mercifully short running time and decent performances throughout, but a sloppy script denies Beastly the hormone-infused gravitas it desperately needs.
While not as execrably dull or insufferably long as the third entry, On Stranger Tides lacks even a basic sense of invention and is keen simply to milk the cash cow for another round...
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Wright proves himself a skilled action director, handling the kinetic requirements of the admittedly fairly routine material with a deft hand, aided entirely by solid performances and a killer soundtrack from The Chemical Brothers.
Though too long and rather padded, this meditative drama derives grand power from the very real connection between its stars, and also that between player and director.

Thomas McCarthy's focus may be far more everyday than his previous films, but Win Win is a resonant, well-crafted drama with standout turns from the ever-brilliant Giamatti and newcomer Alex Shaffer, who is certainly one to watch.
How much you'll go for it depends on whether, like our beleaguered comrades, you partake in a tipple before seeing it...

It's a refreshing rebuke to the countless Brit period dramas and gangster pics we're known for, but for the closure it seems to provide, it should be funnier and develop its characters more. Big fans will probably still enjoy it enough though.
Get past Anne Hathaway's ropey stab at a Yorkshire accent and what you get is a film which understands the devastating but also very funny heart of its source material.
It's not quite as bad as expected, but it still makes more jokes out of the male genital region than any film aimed at children ever should.
It unquestionably sparkles visually and the very youngest kids will still enjoy it, but between Cars 2 and particularly Pixar's three previous features stands a wide chasm of quality.
It boasts more than its share of "WTF!?" moments in the third reel, but it's not enough to salvage an otherwise tedious film that's thin on charm and thrills.
On the surface this is a relatively familiar prison thriller, yet when executed with panache of such disarming brutality and tension, it finds room to distinguish itself in an overcrowded genre.
This grim Aussie thriller derives unnerving power from the unspoken truths during tense silences, ominously closing doors that seal fates, and the disturbing banality of evil.

Bear with the slow start and what you get in this bookending instalment's latter two acts is more pathos, exhilaration, and sheer entertainment value than anything else in the entire eight-film, ten-year saga. Potter has certainly saved the best for last.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Trust centers around a horrible event, but it's the uncomfortable shades of grey - as well as the outstanding performances - which make it smart, original and utterly compelling.

With its dense examination of legal philosophy, it's probably going to interest law graduates more than anyone else, but for the patient viewer, The Conspirator is a treat of performance and benefits from Robert Redford's typically stately direction.
Hanks and Roberts clearly seem up for a work-out, but this dull rom-com holds any potential chemistry at the mercy of poor jokes, a meandering plot and unlikeable supporting characters.

It's still chock full of embarrassing humour and soap opera drama, but Dark of the Moon is, thanks to a dizzyingly impressive near-hour climax, more a celebration of Bay's strengths than a laundry list of his many flaws. But only just.
To an entire generation of filmgoers, it just might represent the most significant leap in storytelling that they will ever see...

Bad Teacher could have dared to push the 15-rating further, and it probably would have been funnier as a result, but on the back of a refreshingly irreverent turn from Cameron Diaz, the flaws are easy to forgive.
Dramatically uneven though well-performed and competently directed, Holy Rollers features an intriguing premise yet treads thin ice when battling an inconsistent script.
Little more than a dull if mercifully brief promotional feature for the Olympics.

Despite having to wade through no end of sigh-inducing clichés, Sly actually comes off better here than many of his co-stars, a rather unfortunate result of...bit-part actors who may well have been dragged off the street and paid in ham sandwiches.

It is the sort of film that shouldn't be cynically propping itself up with a name draw like Pattinson, but more importantly, it is the sort of film that should rouse the mind rather than dullen it with pretensions to the lectern.
Oblivion is one of the best-looking bad films ever made.
Shane Carruth continues to grow as a filmmaker even as he remains keen to puzzle and perhaps frustrate. Upstream Color is, above all else, an unforgettable experience.
Though not without its stirring moments, this documentary takes far too long to make what is admittedly a pretty important point about British agricultrure.
The most infuriating and sinister documentary in recent memory.
Save for a star turn from veteran character actor Josh Pais, Lynn Shelton's latest is pretty much dead on arrival.
Go for the thrilling action and hilarious Shane Black one-liners. As for a compelling story and entertaining villains? Not so much.
A sumptuously assembled, exhaustively comprehensive film about music that changed lives.
Uncompromising and enormously life-affirming, this is sure to be one of the year's must-see documentaries.
Though undeniably well-intentioned, Barbara Kopple's documentary doesn't seem particularly concerned with asking - or trying to answer - the big questions surrounding familial suicide trends.
This immaculately composed heist flick-cum-morality play just might bring Hollywood knocking on Sean Ellis' door.
An efficient talking heads doc that celebrates the band without deigning to hagiography.
Serves as an uproarious coming out party for writer-director-lead Lake Bell, and you'll never watch a movie trailer the same way again.
Steve Coogan delivers a knock-out performance that renders the central figure in all of his complexity - at once admirable, deplorable and pitiable.
It ultimately amounts to little more than a 90-minute-long gay joke that loses its charm after just a few.
Go in knowing as little as possible and prepare to be blown away by Derek Cianfrance's American crime drama masterpiece.
The irony is that in playing its silly premise dead straight, the film becomes a goldmine of unintentional hilarity.
Disappointingly opts for broad humour over genuine drama in its second half, but anyone who has been through a similar situation will find it undeniably resonant.
Boozed-up students might enjoy it, but it's just going to make anyone over the age of 21 feel really old.
A perfectly functional sequel that nevertheless falls rather short of 2009′s water-tight reboot.
This just might be the only instance in cinema franchise history where the heavy implication of a sixth sequel actually seems appealing.
This is another Baz Luhrmann film that fails to engage either the heart or the mind.
Heli is a combination of neo-realism and visceral brutality, absolutely unforgiving in the depths it dares audiences to plunge.
The problem with The Bling Ring is that it is very nearly as vapid as the people that it depicts.
A virtuoso masterpiece from a director who has instantly made herself one to watch.
Fans of the director craving another toothed, bracing effort will find themselves very much at home here.
An exceptional dramatic feature propelled by strong performances across the board.
Hitchcockian in the most lurid sense of the word.
Farhadi ably acquits himself with a somewhat overlong but largely absorbing depiction of family turmoil.
While it might be their most slight and unfocused effort in almost ten years, given their corpus of work therein, it's difficult to feel too short-changed about that.
A dispiriting uphill climb destined to disappear into obscurity once its day at the Croisette is done.
A riotous breakthrough for Mike Birbiglia, whose humanist comedy says a lot about modern relationships that many of us won't be prepared to admit.
Hirokazu directs a difficult scenario with sensitivity, but also plenty of mirth, emotional warmth and dramatic aplomb.
By parading out every tired trope from the sci-fi and horror genres, Dark Skies is unintentional self-parody, and quite dreadful indeed.
How much you'll bite down on Boyle's shtick will probably depend on your own suggestibility.

Perhaps not a great Tarantino film, but an extremely enjoyable one nevertheless, Django Unchained is a thoroughly excessive, gore-soaked odyssey that's blessed with outstanding performances - especially one from Leonardo DiCaprio - above all else.
Another glorified remake in denial, Texas Chainsaw is an early contender for the worst film of 2013.
Sleazy but dull, this glorified TV movie continues the self-destruction of the once-talented Walter Hill's career.
See through the contrivances and Broken City is taut, potent genre entertainment, girded by a stellar cast.
Daniel Day-Lewis gives yet another performance for the ages in Steven Spielberg's admirably literate, thoroughly charming biopic.
A suitably lightweight comeback for Arnie, The Last Stand does just enough to please his legion of fans, and proves the action icon still has charisma to spare.
A punishing exercise in brain cell annihilation that shoots for edgy but mostly settles for inane petulance.
Little here is truly remarkable, but it's the variety that keeps it bounding long.
An authoritative, beautifully assembled, personal, even romantic account of one of rock music's most important waypoints, a film which aficionados absolutely should not miss.
Credibly acted and hardly much worse than the original, but just as bereft of atmosphere and by-the-numbers.
movie_title: The Haunting in Connecticut 2: Ghosts of Georgia (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Charlie Sheen proves he still has something to contribute, but like us, he's defenceless against Roman Coppola's inchoate script.
movie_title: A Glimpse Inside the Mind of Charles Swan III (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Stylishly efficient and well acted horror fare that doesn't bash the viewer over the head with its mythology.
This sentimental, lightweight biopic is more concerned with the childish passive-aggressiveness of Hitchcock's marriage than the inner-workings of his artistic mind.

If you thought that Amy Berg's Deliver Us from Evil had extracted every last word on the issue of child abuse in the Catholic Church, Alex Gibney proves with his new film that there's still plenty left to be infuriated about.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Benefiting hugely from rock-bottom expectations, G.I. Joe: Retaliation sets a low bar that it clears effortlessly thanks to Johnson's charismatic performance and a humourous script that demonstrates surprising political awareness.
Wirkola aims for camp but overshoots, causing things to feel less like Sam Raimi and more like Uwe Boll.
John McClane's latest outing delivers everything you should expect from the minds responsible for tripe like Max Payne and X-Men Origins: Wolverine.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A wiry slice of subversive Southern Gothic that will go down a treat with teens who consider themselves too smart for Twilight.
Though minimalist to a fault, there's plenty of tension to keep this grisly Aussie thriller bounding along.
An undeniably relaxing sit, though one which also proves meandering on one too many occasions.
Austin and Lundgren fare surprisingly well in the talkier scenes, though the lack of action will test even the most enthusiastic audiences.
A moderately entertaining, no-frills crime caper shot through with enthusiasm by its talented cast.

Difficult to criticise aesthetically or on the basis of its performances, Verity's Summer is nevertheless a promising but perplexing debut feature let down by a low narrative pulse that makes it difficult to care.
This amiable oddball comedy should push things further, but it nevertheless earns a steady stream of laughs.
The whole endeavour invites a sure feeling of pointlessness, but it's as beautifully shot and gore-soaked as these retreads come.
London's never looked so good, yet outside of the crackling action scenes, there's very little on offer.
Hollywood's cynicism knows no bounds. They're now remaking bad movies too.
DreamWorks' latest is a lusciously mounted but simple-minded adventure that won't long linger in your memory.
Though this isn't quite rock-bottom for Nicolas Cage, that's hardly saying much these days.
A sexy, seductive portrayal of one young man's downward spiral into existential Hell on the chilly Parisian streets.
It all ends with a ludicrously mishandled plot twist guaranteed to send audiences into paroxysms of laughter. A feel good film indeed, then.
Though his latest film plunges deep into the heart of southern American parochialism, Minervini has crucially forgotten to engage us on an emotional level.
A shakily uneven return for the director, entrenched in the more laborious, bone-dry methodology of its famous case study rather than probing the complex emotional state of the titular character.
Grand Central wipes away the cobwebs of trite Hollywood romance to deliver something truly difficult to shake.
No child or parent deserves to be subjected to something so effortless and cynical. Top Cat: The Movie is a rarity; an almost completely mirthless, charmless animated film.

While it doesn't quite subvert genre expectations as much as it could have, You're Next delivers irreverent thrills by way of savage violence, lashings of dark humour, and a steely performance from Sharni Vinson.
Despite drawing influence from a fascinating real-life event, this sloppily directed, largely tension-free found footage film sticks too closely to genre formula.
It's great to see Zach Galligan on the big screen again, but Hatchet III serves up a host of unimaginative kills stymied by terrible gore effects. Strictly for fans of the series.
This entry is even more inconsistent than the original, also suffering from oft-incomprehensible coverage and another dull wrap-around story.
A potently satirical realisation of what "dog eat dog" business strategy really means.
A ride worth taking, even if the ending feels like a deliberate middle-finger to the audience.
It gets a few points for its technical audacity, but at times Daylight borders on senselessness.
Though wearing its meta tone on its sleeve, Sadik 2 takes far too long to engage with its twisty concept, and is painfully subject to a subterranean budget.
By title alone, The Paranormal Diaries: Clophill might sound like a lame, straight-to-video Paranormal Activity ripoff, and that's because it essentially is.
Coasts on a brilliant performance from Lara Flynn Boyle, even if it's strictly for fans of the stoner movie formula.
This unconvincing techno-horror is too self-serious to be entertaining, but also too silly to be taken seriously.
What begins as compelling and enigmatic eventually loses its way to a more familiar horror film scenario.
A smart, stylish psychological thriller boosted by stellar performances and a unique engagement with its schizophrenic protagonist.
A deeply ugly film from top to bottom, but more importantly, how can a collaboration between Lohan, Deen, Ellis and Schrader be so dull?
An inoffensive enough Nordic thriller that nevertheless completely blows its interesting premise.
Barely one step above a middling Game of Thrones fan-film, albeit executed with little of the passion that this would imply.
While it builds palpable tension early on, No One Lives de-evolves into a generic torture porn gorefest in its second half, becoming increasingly absurd as it does so
It's hard to think of a lazier, less-ambitious blockbuster in recent memory.
The first Israeli zombie flick does little to elevate itself above the garden variety entries to the genre, suffering from poor acting, a generic plot, and laughable visual effects.
This unabashedly nostalgic doc serves as a potent reminder of VHS' pivotal role in the history of entertainment, even if we've all moved on now. Well, most of us.

Certainly provides plenty of fascinating insight into the human suspension community, even if most viewers will probably still struggle to relate to shoving hooks through their body in the pursuit of enlightenment.
The video game-inspired visuals, pulsing synth score and manic level of energy make it quite the ride indeed.
movie_title: Bring Me the Head of the Machine Gun Woman (Tráiganme la cabeza de la mujer metralleta) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Ultimately disappointing due to an inane script which fashions a thoroughly unlikable, idiotic protagonist who invites derision more than sympathy.

Disappointingly resorts to a reductive dissection of its protagonist in the third reel, but The Grief Tourist benefits from Michael Cudlitz's suitably creepy performance, and is an atmospheric, suspenseful ride.
As both a compelling examination of conspiracy theorists and a unique found footage film, The Conspiracy lays firm groundwork before delivering a tense, dynamic third act.
The Pastors prove what can be done with a modest budget when you strip away the Hollywood excess.
When a movie directed by Stephen Sommers doesn't even get a theatrical release, you know something's up.
Riddick lacks the soulless, mechanised groan of the previous film, but even stripping away the excess, this disappointing jaunt has very little meat on its bones.
Decisively earns the commendation of "sweaty palm movie of the year."
This thinly-premised WW2-set found footage flick just about succeeds by way of its excellent creature designs and unexpectedly clever political gags.
There's much to like in James Mangold's take on X-Men's mutton-chopped superhero, but little mistaking the overall wonkiness of the enterprise.
Though darker and in many ways more cavalier than either of its predecessors, the third time is most certainly an ambitious, uproarious, insane, bromantic charm.
Unexpectedly hollow and corny as Hell, but set your brain to cruise control and it also delivers (eventually) on its promises of crowd-pleasing, rock 'em, sock 'em action.
A rousing documentary that will affirm your love for both cinema and life.
Damn-near destined to endure as a cult classic and high-point of contemporary Dutch cinema.
The movie equivalent of a noisy, hyperactive child screaming in your face.
This slight, deliberate tale of strained families keeps the audience at a distance, making it a curiously uninvolving sit that rarely engages on even the most basic level.
It amounts to little more than a fecklessly bloodless gimmick thriller.
An absurd yet entertaining thriller that dispenses with the preciousness of the Cannes Film Festival's In Competition banner.

The busload-full of skilled actors Canet has brought with him damn-near ensures a compelling sit, even if the film's ponderous pacing and resulting length do detract somewhat from its finer qualities.
A daring if totally misguided hybrid of two very different films that may suffice for the director's fans, though will likely be remembered as a sloppy curio farce above all else.
Bruni Tedeschi's performance is the gemstone of the piece, elevating it considerably.
movie_title: Un château en Italie (A Castle in Italy) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: If this really is the end of the road for Soderbergh, then what a class act to finish on.
It is not so much that Franco has butchered Faulkner's novel as he has inflicted a garish blight upon the art of cinema.
Sorrentino's direction is as crisp as it has ever been, telling one of his more relatable tales.
An ill-organized revenge tale that unfolds in needlessly incoherent fashion, and despite a rather salacious, sexy premise, fails to get the pulse racing.
A heartfelt, understated and sublimely-acted drama about late-blossoming sexuality.
movie_title: Sarah préfère la course (Sarah Would Rather Run) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: An ominous premise gains little traction by way of Puenzo's plodding approach.

Simply, without a brand name like Refn's at the helm, there's no way this project would be In Competition at Cannes, nor would it have attracted its talented stars, nor even found its way out of your local bargain bin.
Ultimately too spare to completely satisfy, the pronounced feeling coming out of this film is that it needs more dancing.
The journey certainly proves more rewarding than the destination, but quite a journey it is.
In daring to so aggressively shake up two formulas for the price of one - the apocalyptic epic and the frat-boy romp - this is a very special comedy indeed.
A rare animated follow-up that makes a concerted effort to develop its characters beyond the established caricature.
In Snyder, Nolan and Goyer, the Man of Steel has found an unlikely dream team able to make him soar once again.
Forster and co. have produced what just might be the dullest zombie movie ever made.
Poor Ashley Bell, a talented and capable actress done few favours in a film that is thoroughly risible from start to finish.
As exhaustive and definitive as fans could ask for, this heavyweight musical will enrapture fans and prove impressive to the uninitiated, also.
A doting yet entertaining puff-piece that will please the band's fans even if it offers little insight into the men or their work.
movie_title: The Stone Roses: Made of Stone (2013)

movie_review_blurb: It's just a shame that Cotillard's impressive performance isn't hung on a more vibrant story.
Cinema of the angriest kind from a hungry new filmmaker keen to provoke.
Payne's latest considers the notion of legacy with quietly heart-wrenching attention to detail, and is one of his sweetest yet most unsentimental films to date.
Kechiche captures the ecstatic highs and punishing lows of matters of the heart with piercing proficiency.
What the director has crafted here is charmless misery porn sorely in need of a personality transplant.
movie_title: The Golden Dream (La Jaula De Oro) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Redford's fiercely committed and quite brilliant performance is the reason to see this daringly minimalist, slightly overlong curio.
A brutally tedious, interminably long costume drama that errantly wastes a fleet of talented actors.
movie_title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas (2014)

movie_review_blurb: This film is pure excess that's almost definitely motivated by studio greed, but it's light entertainment that will please fans, and Andy Serkis damn-near runs away with the film during his exemplary third-act appearance as Gollum.
This tonally buoyant coming-of-age film works as both an off-kilter comedy and a potent drama.
Flight flags when it defers to the more conventional elements of an addiction drama, but Denzel Washington's rousing portrayal gives the picture the fuel to succeed.
Though The Seasoning House is far from a great film - both slow and occasionally harbouring ill logic - it is an enticing calling card for its director.
A disappointingly self-indulgent offering from veteran character actor-turned-writer-director Michael Biehn.
This is a breezy, to-the-point thriller.
You're going to want a shower after this one.
movie_title: Hidden In The Woods (En las afueras de la ciudad) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: V/H/S is a meaty, full-fat horror anthology and like all of them, brings with its frequent terror plenty of flaws.
As well as ditching the handheld gimmick and serious tone, Genesis has also jettisoned the spirit that made the first two films so riotously entertaining.
This is a scholarly assessment of the cult genre, but also a neat, passionate and informed one.
movie_title: Eurocrime! The Italian Cop and Gangster Films That Ruled the '70s (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It plays out like a dull mission from a particularly naff first-person-shooter video game.
The dullest of 3D experiences and a calamitous failure of intention.
A film of two halves - one dull, the other exciting and funny.
If Tommy Wiseau were to ever have a go at making a Giallo film, it would probably end up something like this.
What really impresses is how much passion drips out of the subjects. A must-see for any horror fan.
Wrong Turn 4 is among the worst and most insultingly asinine horror films ever made.
It's stylishly constructed and a better feminist vampire yarn than Twilight, but still problematic in itself.
A film far better than it has any right to be by title alone.
Luis Tosar is electrifying as every tenant's worst nightmare in this deeply unsettling, shrewdly measured slice of Hitchcock.
This is efficient, intelligent horror that stays with you.
A wickedly funny bout of body horror that also cuts deep.
The actors try hard, but the mercilessly derivative, emotionally pat script stifles their efforts at every corner.
Chained is confronting cinema like we rarely see, even with its share of hiccups.
The Possession is funnier and better-acted than many similar films, but still feels awfully rote.
The interesting premise is undermined at every turn by idiotic characters and overwhelming contrivance.

Dredd is a rare reboot both necessary and successful, doing what Stallone's stolid effort couldn't with double the budget - excite, entertain, and stay crucially true to John Wagner's unwaveringly dark vision.
An abject failure as both a slick actioner and a familial drama, Taken 2 signs its series' own death warrant.

A coming-of-age film for the ages, Perks will charm even ardent cynics, with a rousing script, breathless soundtrack, and three stunning performances, particularly from the enormously talented Ezra Miller.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's clear that the Activity has become too normal for all but the die-hards.
Perhaps not a vital examination of the indelible icon, but a frank, funny, and thoroughly captivating one.

In many ways Frankenweenie is the apotheosis of Tim Burton's style, as well as a reminder of his strengths and weaknesses; it is emotionally neutered and keen to self-plagiarise, but beautifully formed and a lot of fun.
Though it seems authentic, that doesn't stop it from being a bit tedious.
Haneke's film is unquestionably the feel-bad film of the year, refreshingly lacking in sentiment and absolutely devastating, but also abuzz with the joys that make life worth living.
A stupendous is-it-isn't-it horror film marked by a disarming audaciousness both technical and creative.

While it's unquestionably great to see Arnie again toting a giant gun, The Expendables 2 fails to make the most of its game cast, and most surprisingly of all, is quite lacking in the action department.
Rachel Weisz is the best thing in this overlong slog through Matt Damon's table scraps.
Sometimes people deserve more. Sometimes people deserve to have their faith rewarded. And with The Dark Knight Rises, Nolan's masterful coda, he has done just that.
A passionate, deeply affecting celebration of a medium too often derided.
A slight, touching tale of extraordinary human adaptability.
Beyond their admittedly inspired setting, the filmmakers lack even an iota of invention.
The appallingly self-serious Abraham Lincoln: Vampire Hunter is stylised to death and lacks the subversion needed to support its inspired premise.
A few solid observations aside, this is the urban thriller running on low-fi autopilot.
A disarming tableau about life, love and death, Aleksei Fedorchenko's lyrical drama is soup for the soul.
As far as adaptations of self-help books go, this one - which bites back at the source material - is one of the recent best.
This is a grown-up rom-com that incredibly doesn't outstay its welcome despite a meaty runtime, because Blunt and Segel create charming characters who are easy to root for.
Rebecca Hall gets an A-for-effort, but her blinding performance is mostly squandered in this vanilla crime farce.
Effective at studying a physical specimen, but as an examination of a man in terms of what he means to his family and his country, the context is fatally scarce.
Overlong and mind-numbingly generic, Joyful Noise promises home-cooked charm but leaves a taste worse than day-old grits.
Jennifer Westfeldt continues to forge a strong reputation as a writer of humanist romance.
Unexpectedly lofty and well-produced, but overlong and not ado about enough.
Few films capture the vibe of live music as well as this sublime documentary.
movie_title: Glastonbury: The Movie in Flashback (Glastonbury: The Movie) (1995)

movie_review_blurb: A grim treatise on the origins of violence, with excellent performances from the largely unknown young cast.
Garfield is a fine substitute for Maguire, but didn't we already see this film ten years ago?
Matthew McConaughey steals the show with a ferocious, transformative performance worthy of awards attention, and Friedkin restores his stature as an architect of taut, muscular cinema.
A funnier, deadly ironic ending was surely on the cards, but even without, this is a disarming, largely entertaining smattering of philosophies and worldviews.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Easily the best film ever made about male strippers.
Pasts both collective and personal are thoughtfully examined in Patricio Guzmán's ethereal documentary.
A long, challenging film that's also thoroughly gripping, and largely due to its virtuoso climactic sequence, quite the bravura feat of film-making indeed.
Tony Kaye's penchant for piercing filmmaking hasn't gone anywhere.
A thoughtful, sinewy thriller that takes its time, but girds on a stellar, stoic performance from Willem Dafoe.
All it took was a director of David Ayer's ingenuity to bring the oft-maligned found footage genre back into repute.
Even with six world-class directors, it all amounts to a pretty uninteresting collage of Cuban life.
Go for the spot-on rant about Diablo Cody, but stay for the chaotic, vital commentary on a noxious cultural milieu.
A terrifying doc that only grows more fascinating and infuriating as its filmmakers, drawn into the drama themselves, let go of their impartiality.
Ping Pong makes a firm case that a strong spirit will aid your longevity. It is a documentary both irreverently funny and deeply affecting.
The film is, as Clarke's hooded Kidulthood character might say, 'well gash, innit'.
The wit and charm of the series' earlier entries, and much of their visual splendour, appears to have evaporated.
There is so much good in the first hour that you can just about forgive its poorly written third act.
What begins as a tender romance soon enough devolves into overwrought melodrama.
A documentary as idiosyncratic as its tireless contributors, Room 237 is first and foremost an ode to film fandom in all of its gleeful obsessiveness.
A comprehensive, well-structured deconstruction of an important socio-political moment.

Vinterberg's acidic, important and brilliantly infuriating thriller reaches the heights of his best work, cannily examining the psychology of mob mentality, and bound to leave viewers in a state of high anxiety.
It won't diminish Sam Mendes' extraordinary achievement to say that those wanting a Bond film by way of Christopher Nolan shan't be disappointed. The pleasure is all ours, James.
An enjoyably broad romp that stays light on its feet, and O'Dowd's madman riffing keeps it bounding along.
This exquisitely assembled film, driven by Larrain's pin-sharp direction and Bernal's rousing performance, turns a potentially dry subject into something uproariously funny and massively involving.
Occasionally charming and well acted - especially by Maggie Smith - if memorable largely as Dustin Hoffman's game first foray behind the camera.
A familiar story effectively re-invented, My Brother the Devil deals heartbreak, suspense and hope in equal measure.
More a testament to the fastidiousness of film restoration than Lubitsch's narrative, The Loves of Pharoah is strictly for the curious cinephile.
A padded but entertaining Scandinavian thriller made memorable thanks to its timely economic context.
More enjoyable as an exploration of Parra's music than her life, and well-performed by lead Francisca Gavilán.
Another dynamite vehicle for John Hawkes, in which Lewin's affecting script overcomes his pedestrian direction.
A regal, stately biopic about, oddly enough, the politics of eating a hot dog, that's underwritten and poorly cast.
It's unapologetically scattershot, but for the subject's fans, bound to be absolutely hilarious.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A dreary, tiresome dirge about passion and dis-passion, if memorably performed by impressive lead Hadas Yaron.
An ingeniously conceived thriller that's almost as much about our collective love of cinema as it is a tricky international incident.
Introspective but rarely cerebral, The Wall is too frustratingly obtuse despite boasting a solid central performance and lush visuals.
The Comedian is a fatally underwritten curio that doesn't give its competent actors enough to work with.
Scott Graham's striking debut oozes atmosphere and is well worth the slow-burn.
An affable kitchen sink drama distinguished by astonishing turns from the kids Michael Winterbottom watched grow over five years.
A low-energy Argentinian thriller that hasn't got a clue what it should do with Viggo Mortensen's reliably committed performance.
Joel Edgerton nurses the hangover from Hell in this superbly acted, impressively edited and consistently engaging Aussie thriller.
A clever meta-narrative achievement that boasts winningly naturalistic performances from the real inmates and doesn't outstay its welcome.
The painstakingly over-methodical approach gives this the feel of a first-time director trying a little too hard, or perhaps not hard enough.
movie_title: De jueves a domingo (Thursday Till Sunday) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Without a single bullet in sight, Craig Zobel has crafted an ingenious, dizzying conversation piece of a thriller.

Mira Nair again reminds us of her frustrating inconsistency as a filmmaker, enlisting a fine cast and strong technicals - Declan Quinn's sumptuous cinematography is particularly enchanting - but failing to cover the, ahem, fundamentals first.
This is one film that doesn't have all or seemingly many of the answers, nor does it pretend to; Anderson's work is a snapshot of a time, one that develops in the viewer's mind long after a sitting.
A sacrilegious adaptation of an excellent video game, Silent Hill: Revelation will infuriate gamers, and just confuse everyone else.
We need little more proof as to Gambit's quality than the simple fact that the Coen Brothers chose to pawn their script off on another director rather than film it themselves.
All style and no substance, Rise of the Guardians' gorgeous visual presentation boasts a lot more dimension than its underwhelming script.
Mary Elizabeth Winstead is the jaw-dropping stand-out in this gripping addiction drama, which examines the toxic power of alcohol with probing intimacy.
This relentlessly hilarious and quietly moving riff on middle-aged growing pains stands as a rare spin-off that outdoes the material it spawned from, and is Judd Apatow's best feature to date.
Easily the best animated film in a year full of crushing disappointments, Wreck-It Ralph is a heart-warming ode to retro gaming that will enrapture gamers and pretty much everyone else along the way.
Flipping a police car is not a work of art, and neither is this film.
A ghastly, shockingly inept piece of filmmaking.
Doing the right thing is never as easy as it seems in Lenny Abrahamson's sublimely acted and almost unbearably tense drama.
This is delirious, visionary filmmaking of a high order; an insidious, sinewy thriller and the best film made by anyone named Cronenberg in quite a while.
A jaw-droppingly ambitious effort; a lavish, mental, messy and moving event-film-cum-tone-poem that rewards patient, open-minded viewers.
A straight-forward telling of an affecting, devastatingly funny tale, topped by a magnificent lead performance from Kim Kold as Ken, the gentle giant.
For what it's worth, Grassroots features Cedric the Entertainer's best performance to date.
Briskly paced and as funny as it is emotionally resonant, Sister is easy viewing despite a potentially grim premise.
An excessively formalistic approach does Antonio Méndez Esparza little favours in his bloated, flavourless feature debut.
The ground of WW2 has been so firmly-trodden that this quietly involving take from another perspective feels like a welcome punch in the gut.
An exhausting, challenging, even draining but richly powerful film about a crisis between friendship and faith.
Not without a few perverse, unintentional charms, but only recommendable to the most morbidly curious of viewers.
A portentous, sub-BBC production in which no corrupt cop trope is left unturned.
An hysterically funny, breathlessly paced and moving meditation on old age and existence, topped by an award-worthy turn from Frank Langella. One of the year's best.
Like Garrone's Gamorrah, it's messy and bloated, but Reality is also a fiendishly amusing, eerie examination of the current trends of celebrity.
Uneven, frustrating and occasionally brilliant, but unsatisfying overall.
movie_title: Sono yoru no samurai (The Samurai That Night) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: What impresses most is the consistent, clear tone and vision throughout; the comedy never up-ends the thoughtful elements, nor the other way around. Balance is key, and as such, Doomsday Book is well worth the long wait.
Save Your Legs does little favours for either the sport of cricket or the country of Australia.
Director Robert Connolly offers up a tinge of The Social Network's sexed-up style, but he's not fortunate enough to have been blessed with a Sorkin-grade screenplay.
Enormous levels of conceit betray marvellous performances and evocative cinematography, but Beasts of the Southern Wild just about does the job.
Miwa Nishikawa's darkly funny if unjustifiably over-long farce is well worth the slog.
A winning marriage of mind-boggling visual effects, excellent performances, and sumptuous direction, Rust and Bone is an emotional, richly rewarding drama.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Francois Ozon's interplay between narrative and meta-narrative girds this smart if occasionally too-precious drama.
A unique, tender documentary which contrasts the production line of tinned food with the lives of those who work on it.
A pedestrian script stifles a promising concept, in spite of solid performances.
West of Memphis is less comprehensive and more manipulative than the Paradise Lost films, but a thoroughly engaging condensation of the facts nonetheless.
Simple, swift and a little sad, this debut is far from perfect, but shows real promise.
movie_title: Grand comme le Baobab (Tall as the Baobab Tree) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Ponderous and lofty but not without its laid-back charms and insights.
Ultimately, viewers will be forced to consider whether the film's sparse narrative rewards are worth the 168-minute investment. For most, I imagine the answer is no.
Unfortunately, great music can only distract us so much in this disappointing feature from the talented Mat Whitecross.
The raw, sweet promise of the first act is ultimately up-ended by its turn towards grimness, but Kelly + Victor is a melancholic meditation on the most disturbing type of romantic irony.
The only thing this film likes more than the sound of its own voice is the sound of the talented actors speaking it.
It's far too long and sags throughout, but this is a simple story well told, and the timing couldn't be better.
A sweet story that's beautifully animated and will appeal to not only kids but adults also.
A bizarre and irreverent if slightly repetitive portrait of picaresque drum legend Ginger Baker.
The mere completion of Al-Mansour's film is a towering achievement in itself; that it's also got charm and heart to spare is icing on the cake.

movie_review_blurb: It's a truly thoroughgoing triumph.

[Allen's] most purely delightful film in many years.
